ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-ss6:0.4_0: The second training rule on receiving food
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-ss6:1.1_0: At one time when the Buddha was staying at Sāvatthī in Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery,
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-ss6:1.2_0: At that time there was a beautiful nun called Sundarīnandā.
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-ss6:1.3_0: When people saw her in the dining hall, they were affected by lust, and they gave her the best food.
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-ss6:1.4_0: Being afraid of wrongdoing, Sundarīnandā did not receive it.
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-ss6:1.5_0: a nun who, without a companion, said to her,
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-ss6:1.10_0: “What can this man do to you, whether he has lust or not, when you’re without it?
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-ss6:1.11_0: Go on, Venerable, receive it with your own hands, and eat whatever staple or non-staple food he gives you.”
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-ss6:1.12_0: The nuns of few desires complained and criticized her,
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-ss6:1.14_0: ‘What can this man do to you, whether he has lust or not, when you’re without it?
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-ss6:1.15_0: Go on, Venerable, receive it with your own hands, and eat whatever staple or non-staple food he gives you’?” ...
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-ss6:1.16_0: “Is it true, monks, that a nun said this?”
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-ss6:1.17_0: ‘What can this man do to you, whether he has lust or not, when you’re without it?
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-ss6:1.18_0: Go on, Venerable, receive it with your own hands, and eat whatever staple or non-staple food he gives you’?”
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-ss6:1.22_0: ‘What can this man do to you, whether he has lust or not, when you’re without it?
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-ss6:1.23_0: Go on, Venerable, receive it with your own hands, and eat whatever staple or non-staple food he gives you’?
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-ss6:1.24_0: This won’t give rise to confidence in those without it ...”
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-ss6:1.25_0: “And, monks, the nuns should recite this training rule like this:
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-ss6:1.26.1_0: ‘If a nun says, ‘What can she do to you, whether she has lust or not, since you have lust?
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-ss6:1.26.1_1: Go on, Venerable, receive it with your own hands, and eat whatever staple or non-staple food he gives you’? Or she has committed an immediate offense entailing sending away and suspension.’”
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-ss6:2.1.4_0: ...The nun who has been given the full ordination by both Sanghas through a legal procedure consisting of one motion and three announcements that is irreversible and fit to stand—this sort of nun is meant in this case.
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-ss6:2.1.6_0: “What can this man do to you, whether he has lust or not, when you’re without it?
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-ss6:2.1.6_1: Go on, Venerable, receive it with your own hands, and eat whatever staple or non-staple food he gives you, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.”
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-ss6:2.1.7_0: If, because of her statement, the other nun receives staple or non-staple food with the intention of eating it, she commits an offense of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-ss6:2.1.8_0: For every mouthful, she commits a serious offense.
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-ss6:2.1.9_0: At the end of the meal, she commits an offense entailing suspension.
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-ss6:2.1.11_0: this is said with reference to the preceding offenses entailing expulsion.
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-ss6:2.1.13_0: there is an offense as soon as the misconduct is committed, and no pressing is required.
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-ss6:2.1.15_0: she is sent away from the Sangha.
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-ss6:2.1.16_0: He commits an offense entailing suspension:
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-ss6:2.1.17_0: ... Therefore, too, it is called “an offense entailing suspension”.
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-ss6:2.2.1_0: If she urges her on to receive water or a tooth cleaner, she commits an offense of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-ss6:2.2.2_0: If, because of her statement, the other nun receives staple or non-staple food with the intention of eating it, she commits an offense of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-ss6:2.2.3_0: If, when only the male being has lust, she urges her on to eat staple or non-staple food received directly from a male spirit, a male ghost, a _paṇḍaka_, or a male animal in human form, she commits an offense of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-ss6:2.2.4_0: If, because of her statement, the other nun receives staple or non-staple food with the intention of eating it, she commits an offense of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-ss6:2.2.5_0: For every mouthful, she commits an offense of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-ss6:2.2.6_0: When the other monk has finished eating, he commits a serious offense.
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-ss6:2.2.7_0: If she urges her on to receive water or a tooth cleaner, she commits an offense of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-ss6:2.2.8_0: If, because of her statement, the other nun receives staple or non-staple food with the intention of eating it, she commits an offense of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-ss6:2.3.1_0: there is no offense for him.
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-ss6:2.3.2_0: if she urges her on, knowing that he has no lust;
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-ss6:2.3.3_0: if she urges her on, thinking that she is not receiving because of anger;
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-ss6:2.3.4_0: if she urges her on, thinking that she is not receiving because of compassion for the family;
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-ss6:2.3.6_0: if she is the first offender.
ai-pli-tv-bi-vb-ss6:2.3.7_0: The sixth offense entailing suspension is finished.
